text: From old notes -- bottle at tasting. Black with ring. Chocolate coffee aroma. Chocolate coffee minimal fruit vanilla wood medium rich soft body. Not a fan of the style, but good.
(backlog) From beer temple. Dark brune pour with tan head. Chocolate, roasted, fruit and malt aromas. Full bodied brew, flavor follows aromas. Nice.

Bottled Killer Kapowski version. Dark brown pour with a khaki head. Lots of roasted malt and cocoa. Some coffee, a bit of toffee sweetness, and some sweet dark fruit notes. Licorice on the palate along with roasted malt, cocoa, and coffee. Light malt sweetness, dark fruit, and a hint of ashy bitterness.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown/black color porter with a medium size dark brown foamy had with good retention and minimal lacing. Aroma consists of chocolate with light raisins notes and some residual sugar. Taste is dominated by some residual sugar with some chocolate notes and some dry raisins. Body is quite full with good carbonation and light warming alcohol notes.  Overall taste is quite intense and this ends up being a real sipper which I think could be addressed by bring additional attenuation to increase the drinkability factor.

22 oz. bottle, sent from StFun (thanks Josh), pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is a bit oxidized but not too bad, with some fruitiness, cardboard, and chocolate. Flavour brings out notes of raisins and milk chocolate dominantly, with a bit of wet cardboard and a hint of roast. Finishes on notes of milk chocolate and light roast. Though not in prime condition, this has actually aged quite well. Very enjoyable baltic porter.

650 mL bottle courtesy of StFuncool, thanks! I wish I had adamantium claws to deal with all the electrical tape wrapped tightly around the cap these days. But, anyway, it pours a a vinegary, wooded darkish brown sustaining a frothy tanned ring which rested atop. Aromas of leather, banana peppers, raisins, aniseed, toast crumbs, milk chocolate... cardboard? Chestnuts? Yeah, okay. Perhaps some bourbon as well? Tastes of nuts, caramel, yeast, with a touch of heat, ash and toast by mid-palate to swallow. Incredibly reminiscent of a Scotch ale, albeit one whose flavors are a little on the imbalanced-side. Still deciding whether or not I actually like this beer.

Bottle from the deliriumfest cellar sale (guessing this one is a few years old).  Thick dark black pour, ring of light brown carbonation and an awesome aroma of rich black cherries, plums and slightly sweet dark chocolate.  Flavor is just as good as the aroma, black cherry skins, some sweet alcoholic raisins, plums, a little soy/peat and finished with some bitter chocolate.  Even with some slight hints of age, this was stellar.  Would like to get a fresh bottle or a growler to compare.
bottled, thanks to SS, crimson brown pour with thin bubbly foam , aroma is chocolate, dates, roasted nuts, coca cola, flavors of dates, raisin bran, chocolate, malty, rye whiskey, nice

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass, with thanks to Doodler - Ive been trying to track this one down for a while! Poured into my Minneapolis Town Hall glass, showing really nice chocolate brown colour with an opaque core. Medium-thick pale tan head is short lived, with ropey lacing. Nose is tart berries, cocoa powder, wood, and dense fruit, with a whiff of smoke as well. Flavours of tart berries, Tootsie pops, cocoa, very tart, moderate to light carbonation. Good, but not great.

Bottle.  A little all over the place with a wide range of flavors.  It seems like it cant make up its mind between being fantastic and outright offensive.  Somewhere in the middle though there are lots of flavors including chocolate, caramel, smoke, tar, roasted malts, and a large amount of dark fruit.  Despite its brief downfalls, such as a weird carrot juice thing, it remains to be a pretty good baltic porter.  However, it will have a hard time competing against others in its class such as Smuttynose Baltic Porter.

Pours dark unclear amber brown in color with a decent caramel head. The aroma is like a barleywine with some smokiness added. The flavor of sweet roasted and smokey malts with some bitter notes that trail off easily on a smooth but full body.

Bottle @ Dans place, Denver. Pours very dark brown with a fading offwhite head. Aroma of raosted malts, burnt caramel, dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruit. Taste is malts, dark chocolate, caramel, roasted toast, coffee, raisin and other dark fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation. 220212

Pour out of bottle, thanks to Aaron for the pour! Dark brownish black with red at the edges, aroma has notes of cocoa nibs, toffee, dark fruit with raisin, figs, plums, touch of burnt toast.  Taste is a mix of nice roasted coffee, bitter roast, some slight dark fruit, hints of cocoa, touch of biscuit, finishing fairly sweet but dry.  Interesting.

Bottle @ Dans house. Black appearance with a small brown head. Nutty, dark chocolate, caramel, a touch roasty, raisin, plum aroma. Creamy, somewhat burnt, toasty, dark chocolate, toffee, caramel flavor with a creamy mouth feel.
Pours a jet black with tan head. Nose and taste are of dry hops, sweet malts, dark fruits like fig, raisin, plum. A very solid offering.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours mahogany with a thin tan head. Nose is roasty coffee, with dark fruit and sugary dark malt. Taste has the same coffee note, with the same raisin, prune, and dark fruit. Pretty sweet and malty, with a long dark fruit finish. Nice smooth body, well-carbonated, and medium-bodied. Very nice stuff.

Bomber pours dark brown/black with a slight amber hue and a medium tan head. Aroma of soy sauce, dark fruits, chocolate, molasses, and nuts. Taste similar to aroma with slight coffee, very well balanced and drinkable. All the mentioned flavors come together under a nice level or roasted malts ending on a slight bitter note. Really nice, very enjoyable!

In short: A rich and well balanced Porter.  Surprisingly easy to drink.  Very good
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed approximately when 6 months of age.  Bottle sent to me by FullObs, thanks a lot Brett 
The look: Near-black body with red highlights topped by a medium tan head
In long: Nose smells rich with cocoa beans, Fig Newton, milk chocolate and more.  Taste is surprising by its drinkability.  Some roast A lot of desert-like flavors (date squares, Fig Newton, milk chocolate, nougat, mocha coffee) but also a good amount of leafy spicy that provide a good balance.  Mouthfeel was full and creamy.  I went through my bomber as if it was a 5% session stout, thats a good sign.  Named after Walter "Killer" Kowalski, a pro-wrestling star from this TV show where company advertises to reach the coveted 65 to 85 IQ demographic.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Quite good. A little like a dopple bock in some of the malt flavor. Has some flavor of dried fruits soaked in brandy. Serving: Bottle
Bomber bottle from a trade with Dchmela! Nice thick pour with a thin fast disappearing head. Sweet toasty malts with coffee and chocholet balanced in. Fantastic pallet!

My 2000th rating.  A big thank you goes out to all the great bottle shops and beer bars in the DC area who carry a progressive lineup of beer that is always evolving.  Thanks to all those proprietors who take pride in stocking the freshest, best beers available both in the United States but also from all across the world.  I need to say thank you to everyone here on the best, most informed, most unbiased beer related site on the internet; Ratebeer.com.  I have been truly blessed to have found a great number of friends and acquaintances thanks to Ratebeer.  I have been significantly more informed as a result of my Ratebeer participation and have had opportunities to attend tastings and events; big and small, formal and informal, which have afforded me the opportunity to try beers from all over the world.  Thank you to the other DC/Baltimore Ratebeerians who have attended or hosted all of the great tastings I have had the opportunity to attend.  Thank you to all the great Ratebeerian Traders who have been so generous and so kind in trading their beers to me.  Thanks to all the great BeerAdvocate traders who have helped me out when a deal couldnt be worked out on Ratebeer.  Thanks to my wife, who graciously puts up with me when I take her to all the out of the way brewpubs just because they have a top rated Kolsch or Brown Ale.  What makes Ratebeer truly special and truly unique is that we are the very definition of a community centered upon the advocacy of great craft beer.  I am thankful that I can be a part of it and hope that I can give as much to the craft beer community as they have given to me.  A little ironic this is the 200th rating of this beer on our site.  22oz bottle I scored via the BA Gang Bang BIF.  Pours a translucent deep mahogany brown with one ring of creamy off white head.  Nose is sweet, brown sugar, light chocolate, dried fruit, a little cherry, toasted bread.  Flavor is awesome, sweet, malty, cherry, toasted bread, light licorice, chocolate, a little cola, light coffee.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  Very drinkable.

This brew pours a clear dark brown color with a medium light beige head that diminishes steadily. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasty malt, anise bread and chocolate. Medium body with flavors of chocolate malt, black licorice, earth and fruit. The finish is peaty malt and chocolate. Pretty unique, above average beer all around.
Bottle. Almost black and opague. malt, coffee and maple syrup in the aroma. Full bodied. Creamy flavor with chocolate, mocha. Sweet. Hints of licorice in the aftertaste, Well balanced. Good.

Date: October 14, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Trade with FullObs Appearance: Opaque dark brown with slight amount of head. Aroma: Chocolate, roasted, nutty, and maybe some caramel. Flavor: Consistent with aroma except not a sweet chocolate, full bodied, smooth with a slight bitter and alcohol/dry finish. Other: Liked everything about this until the finish.

not cool to name a beer after a killer, this beer murdered my sister!! .. . Pours a deep brown, medium foam .. . chocolate, light roast, and deep fruit roast .. . decent .. . . 

not on our show, skippy!

Bottle shared by phaleslu. Thanks Peter! Pours dark brown with a very thin tan head. Beer seems pretty flat. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, cocoa. Flavor is cocoa, chocolate, coffee and molasses. Medium bodied with little to no carbonation.

22 oz. bottle from TheAlum- thanks, Adam! Killer Kapowski. Should have been wearing my Windy City Rollers shirt when I opened this one. Anyway, I noticed the cap wasnt on very well so I brought it out sooner than I had planned on opening it. Pours a deep, flat cocoa brown with a minimal beige ring. Aroma of chocolate, soy, cocoa powder, molasses, and some hints of oxidation- thanks, weak cap. Flavor of coffee, cocoa, nuts, tobacco, earth, and molasses. The flavor was roastier than the sweeter nose. Not showing the same oxidation as the nose, but there wasnt really any carbonation to speak of. Light-medium bodied. Nice, and probably better fresh and on tap.

Old bottle (2009?) from a trade a long time ago. Pours with a near black body with a small tan head that lasts decently well. Aromas of dark fruits, fig, molasses, tar, light oxidation. Chocolate, subtle fruit notes, bready. Flavors are chewy, fudge, currant, figs and tar. A bit of bready malt. Light oxidation and a hint of a metal flavor. Medium to light bubbles with a fuller body. Smooth, lightly warming.

Aroma is roast, coffee, some malt sweetness, chocolate.  Pours black, tan head with average retention.  Chocolate and roasty flavor, creamy and smooth, sweet caramel notes.  Medium-full body, smooth and silky, medium carbonation.

Bottle from bauermj.  Pours dark brown, some amber highlights sneaking through, with a thin head on top.  The aroma at first is incredibly chocolaty.  Its like opening up a box of fresh assorted chocolates.  A toasty nutty scent with dark fruit follows.  This drinks very smooth and creamy with some ashy notes in the finish.  Getting plenty of the chocolate here too but its maybe not quite as strong as the aroma.  Graham cracker, prune, and a dash of a coffee liquor note gives this some depth.  Slightly roasty but its far more on the creamy side.  This is really solid stuff.  Love the drinkability, wish I had more.

Bottle shared with RB/BA folk...  Poured dark brown, near black with an off-white head.  Really wonderful, some roast and vanilla, and a decent sweetness.  Nice, light body and great yeast character with dark fruits, cherries, cocoa, dark malts, and a clean finish.

(22oz bottle) rich dark brown pour, nice film of wispy offwhite bubbles. Nose of a bit of oxidation, leather, molasses, mildly vegetal and chocolaty. Taste of toasty cracker, bit of dry unsweet chocolate, tiny bit salty, alcohol kick and some nutty elements. Crisp but soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with a grayish brown head that dissipates slowly and completely. Aroma has notes of bittersweet chocolate with a light roasted malt note and a bit of underlying dark fruits. Flavor is similar with chocolate in the start that is joined by some roasted malts that grow through the finish.

66cl Bottle kindly shared by Rciesla and Vtafro at Beer Temple, cheers guys! Deep dark brown to black colour, light beige head. Aroma of sweet rye, some chocolate, dark fruits, roasted malts, a bit bock-like. Flavour is sweet, malty, rye, chocolate, roasted malts, light coffee taste, light bitter malty finish. Light to medium bodied. Nice.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a small white head.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted coffee.  Taste is sweeter with a slightly boozy finish.  Chocolate, roast malt, slight coffee.  Overall just a bit sweeter that I was expecting.  Almost like a sweet stout.  Meh.

Bomber.  Pours a deep cola brown with some jet black highlights and a tiny off white head after an aggressive pour.  A lot of the smokiness comes through on the nose with a woody, chocolate backbone, but not so much smoke in the taste.  The smoke is definitely more along the lines of subtle peat, and not necessarily campfire.  Sweet chocolate dominates the palate along with coffee, dried prunes, and roasted malt.  Full bodied and rather sweet for a baltic porter, yet drinks like a sweet stout.

22oz bottle from sleestak 
Appearance: Pours clear dark brown with a medium beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sour dark malts and chocolate 
Taste: Tart, woody and toasted malts  
Nice, easy drinking

Bomber thanks to Craig. Pours a totally opaque black color with a medium beige head. The aroma is caramel and chocolates. The flavor is a smooth easygoing brew; chocolates, light bitterness. caramel, sugars, sweetness throughout. Nice.

Bottle pours dark brown with tan head.  Aroma a little sour with malts and roast.  Taste sweet malts, roast, caramel, chocolate, a little coffee.  full mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation.  Finish caramel and roast.  Alcohol slightly apparent.  This seems little on the milder side for a Baltic porter but overall its good.
Deep brown pour.  The aroma is rich and chewy.  Soft milk chocolate and a soft chewy sweetness.  Lightly vegetal as it warms up - which is unfortunate.  Meh.

650ml bottle poured into my Bruery tulip, latest batch... Pours with a very dark brown body, a faint hint of amber deep in the center. A light tan head only raises to leave a thing ring. Poor lacing... The aroma is very sweet, tons of milk chocolate, little too sweet for me. A little roasted grain too, smells like a porter, but a little simple... Taste packs much more of a punch. More smoke and bitter coffee notes, gets ride of the sweetness, Im a fan of that. Chocolate pokes its head out on the finish but so does a touch of alcohol. The front is successful but then a little down hill... The mouthfeel is nice, very full and chewy for a porter. 

Slightly above average porter. Drinkable for 8% though.

Bottle that I took Max and Jesss place (since we never got around to opening it post EBF).  Pours a deep dark black with a thin beige head.  Roast and chocolate, cocoa.  Tons of roast, dark fruit, but very faint.  Fuzzy dark fruit notes, warm roast and malt, and some chewy tannins on the finish.

Bottle generously shared at Maxs FF winnings tasting. The name is awesome. Good looking black pour with persistent lacing. Aroma is odd of grass, feet, and caramel. The flavor ismuch better: caramel, pine needles, and coffee grounds. Earthy finish with plenty of wet coffee grounds. I liked it overall but would have had no clue this was a baltic porter.

Bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasted malty aroma, with floral hops, a touch of coffee, and chocolate. The flavor has roasted malts, a light sweetness, and floral hops. Nice.
Bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours black. Tan head. Nose of vanilla and chocolate malt. Taste of coffee, roast chocolate malt, vanilla and dry chocolate finish.

Im pretty sure this bottle is form 2011 and not 2009 since I just recently saw it at my local liquor store.

650ml bottle.

It pours a thick dark brownish black with a foamy light tan head. It leaves some decent lacing as it recedes.

The smell is interesting, it smells like an equal parts mix of plain Perrier, Czech pilsener, and coffee. Weird.

The flavor is the same way oddly enough, a bit roastier though. It has this mineral water quality to it that I dont mind but it just seems odd. It gets better with progressive drinks, and it also gets sweeter.

A bit of an oddity, it is a decent porter.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-02-2011 04:52:10

Bottle from the brewery at Hi-Fi release. Not sure what this Kowalski alias is about, but delicious all the same! Poured brown black with a thin white head. Smell is coffee and chocolate with sweet roasted malts, very rich. Taste is just as rich, smooth and delicious as hoped. Chocolate and roasted malts. Lovin it.
Dark brown pour with a foamy head.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. Flavor is chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, caramel, and roasted malt.  A good all around porter.

From notes.  Tasted from a bottle purchased at Lush Roscoe.  Pours an opaque dark amber with a thick tan head that displays excellent retention.  The nose is sweet roasted malt with chocolate, bitter coffee, and a bit of vanilla.  The flavor is somewhat sweet with dark roast, some smokiness, nuts, coffee, chocolate, and light vanilla.  The body is full and sticky with light carbonation and a long roasty and vanilla finish.
Getting some molasses and raisin aroma. Nice smooth full bodied flavor with a bit of milk chocolate malt and creaminess. A decent sweetness adding an extra bit of body.

Traded bottle. Absolutely gorgeous freakin pour; very lively too. Medium size tan head on top of a black body. Decent lacing. Sweet aroma with some roasted malt and strawberries? Surprisingly full mouthfeel. Coffee, burnt malt, dark sugar and some fruitiness. Very well done.
Bottle thanks to markwise: Poured a dark brown with light corners. The aroma is dark chocolate, fruit, and oldish roasted malt. Taste is more chocolate, roasted malt and hints of dark fruit.

Handbottle from Duane. aroma has big chocolate, licorice, faint hop bitters in the backend. Flavor is all chocolate up front, faint coffee, big pine resin in the finish. Really well rounded for a bigger beer. Mouthfeel is a tad syrupy. Well done.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown/black color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a sweetish roasted malty chocolate finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
Brown red pour with tan head and lace. Chocolate and light coffee aroma. Chocolate, roasted malt, and a good medium bitter. A medium full bodied beer. Very nice

Bottle courtesy of flssmrbrewalum. Pours a nice deep brownish black with a light brown head. Aroma is licorice, chocolate, roasted barley. Flavor is toasted nuts, chocolate, roast, barley, licorice. Also, Some vinous fruity notes delicately linger behind all of it. Nicely balanced and medium bodied with a good dose of bittersweet choco-roast-barley bitterness balanced out with just enough sweetness.

cheers to markwise for the share.
pours dark brown, than/mocha head.
aroma, chocolate, cocoa, some hops and malts.
flavors, light bitter dark chocolate, medium carbonation, notes of roasted malts/coffee, powdery cocoa nibs, touch of yeast and possibly some lingering spices.
Solid brew.

Pours brown with a thin tan head. The aroma is big raisins, prunes, with some chocolate and a hint of coffee. The flavor is pretty much the same with the alcohol noticeable at 8%. Not too sweet and a little anise on the palate. It has  a big roasty, nutty finish.

Bomber of Killer Kapowski shared by hansgrubers crew at DLD.

Pours pretty dark brown with a small off-white head and some decent lacing.

Aroma is nice and roasty.  Coffee, dark fruit notes, and anise as well.

Flavor is somewhat sweet and roasty.  Not too sweet.  Some dark chocolate notes, vanilla, coffee, and earth.  Very slight dried fruit aspect.  Tasty stuff.

Medium-full bodied and fairly smooth.  Pretty dry and slightly bitter on the palate.

Nice beer overall.  I enjoyed this one.

Curtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom! Its black with a red hue and a huge, light-brown, lasting, creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, dark fruits and licorice. The flavour is moderately sweet with notes of roasted malt, licorice, vanilla, light dark fruit and the finish is dry. Its a nice one.

Had at the Rav Pig during RBWG 2010!  Big sweet chocolate up front with some malt.  The flavor is a bit lighter, but still full of malt, cocoa powder, milk chocolates, cream, and more. This is good stuff.
bottle, pours black with a thin tan head.  Toffee and espresso aroma.  Sweet upfront chocolate ice cream turns lightly peaty with some heat from the alcohol.  I like it.

Aroma is dark malt-anise/molasses, dark fruit.  Taste is dark malt-anise/molasses, dark fruit, secondary earthy hops.
tasting on 3/6/10.  dark brown pour with small tan head... roasted malt aroma... medium body with notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts and some lingering dark fruits... very nice Baltic Porter.
dark amber brown color. creamy and sweet aroma.  tastes like a smooth ceamy taste.  great feel and mild aftertste.  great!

Bomber poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, vanilla, light roastiness and a hint of coffee. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of bitter chocolate, vanilla, light roastiness and a hint of coffee with a smooth lingering chocolate finish.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip. Beer is black and has nearly no head at all. Carbonation is low and there is no lacing. 

Aroma is slightly sour but mostly sweet and roasty.

Beer is medium to light in body, was expecting more body but oh well, slight roast, some chocolate maybe, now Im picking up some chocolate in the aroma as well. There is a growing bitterness in the back of the mouth. Drinkability is fine as well as mouthfeel.

09 bottle courtesy of flandersned. nice bottom ferment porter, i like it but am not super crazy about the syrupy lager finish and aftertaste. otherwise the flavors are great, the nice, and it has a nice medium body.
Bottle at toncatchers 2.  Dryish.  black.  Fast fading small tan head.  Hint of some chocolate. I prefer sweeter beers.

Thanks to MReusch for this amazing bottle! Thick black pour with a creamy tan head. Wonderful interplay of cocoa, dark fruits (fig, raisin, plum) and roasted grains in the aroma. Taste is dominated by a wonderful smooth chocolate and cocoa with some hints of roasted grain poking through. Just an awesome brew.

I really liked this. Dark reddish brown, big beige head. Nicely fruity, coffee-ish aroma. Really easy to drink, smooth without being thin, definately quaffable. Tastes like coffee and prune and other dark fuits, really nice mix of sweet and bitter. Dries out a bit as it warms. Very nice brew. Thanks, Secret Santa!

Bottle. Dark reddish brown with a medium off white head. Liquorice, roasted malt and espresso coffee in the aroma. The flavour is mainly roasted malt with notes of coffee and chocolate. Soft and creamy texture. Very nice.

22 oz bought at brewpub. Pours dark and cola like. Lots of chocolate in the first sip. Some fruit too. Aroma doesnt stand out, but the taste is a brown sugar/cocoa concoction. Nice. Not the football drinking beer Im making it be...but good.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2010 Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Almost black - white head. Oxidation, metallic, light cardboard, fruity, burned, berries, chocolate, bread, light sourness. Sorry - its bad/infected !!! (5/3/3/2/9) - ReRate: Roasted. Light burned. Bitterness. Not infected. Light smokey. Licorice. Very nice. Ryrbread.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark red brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is light heavy malty, roasted, burnt, licorice. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, english licorice acidic notes. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft. [20091123]

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of Tweety. Clear dark brown with a small light brown head. Hard roasted malt in the nose. Medium body, hard roasted malt and a little vanilla and licorice. Mouthfeel is a litle tired. Discreetly bitter. 231109
Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, chocolate and caramel notes. Flavour was sweet with roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and hints of toffee. Finished sweet.

cloudy brown, small brown head
slightly boozy, gorasted grains, 
flavor is faint dark fruits, sweetnes, brown sugar, faint chocolate (good chocolate). it all melts together to give a very nice sweet impression.

Bottled. Deep reddish brown coloured. Light brown head. Roast, fruits, coffee, light molasses in the aroma. Flavour of coffee, roast, herbs, caramel, dust and fruits. Medium to full bodied. Dry roasty light bitterness.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and chocolate. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, chocolate, and lighter notes of alcohol, leading to a dry alcoholic chocolate finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted chocolate and malty. Sweet and roasted malt flavoured. Bitter and roasted flavoured. Roasted and light fruity to bitter base into the finish. Bitter and roasted finish.

Thanks to fishingnet for sharing this one.  Pours dark brown/ black with an off-white head.  Nose is dark fruit, chocolate, roast, smoke, and lots of awesomeness.  Flavor matches this level of awesomeness with the 8% ABV hidden real well.  Add to that vanilla, complexity, love, chocolate, plums, burnt sugar, and fruit.  Excellence in a bottle.

Sampled from 22-oz bomber as Killer Kapowski during Darkness Day 2009 in Brooklyn Center, MN. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with light tan head that slowly dissipates to a thin film top. Aroma of caramel malt, dark chocolate, a hint of candi sugar and coffee. Taste is full bodied, flavors of roasted dark malt, chocolate, a hint of coffee and some candi sugar. Finish is semi-sweet that slowly disappears.

Big thanks to fishingnet for scoring yet more tasty Flossmoor brews. Pours deep mahogany with tan head. The aroma has chocolate, some roast and then it seems to move into thick dark fruity esters. The taste begins creamy with some velvety pelt like fuzziness bringing a touch of earthiness and then rich chocolate. By midway it moves into more earthiness and loads of musty prunes, dates and figs. It ends with drying roastiness and chocolate. All the chocolate is pretty darn yummy and amazing but pulls this a bit out of style. But big deal. Its damn good.
bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  Pours dark brown/black with thinnish head. Aroma of chocolate and vanilla.  Flavor is ash, malt, caramel, coffee.. everything good.  Really good beer.

22 oz. bottle - second time trying this one; thanks Tom and Colin!!  thin, cola brown with aromas of toffee and bread; texture is quite thin and comes of slightly on the sweet side; raw candy and sugar; love the nose, but comes off kind of bland

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  The  smell is malts, chocolate, coffee, toasty, and roasty.  The look is brown to black in color with a beige colored head.  The taste is malts, roasty, coffee, and chocolate.

First Flossmoor, risng star,  Black is the colour, a tiny Caesar head, perhaps truncated by cap crooked off...a little worse for shipping but still a great baltic. Mellowed, as understated carbonation perhaps reflecting shipping, coca-cola-ish mixed with Baltic.  It refreshes, its on the sweet side. Above average mouthfeel.

From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 09/10/2008
Fruit and some roast aroma. Black and strong in alcohol with a little dryness in a crisp and bitter roast finish.
Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Deep brown in color with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt and dark fruit. Taste is of roasted malt, light licorice, and chocolate.
bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  deep brown with a cream head. nose is chocolate, sweet malts and fruit. nice thickness and a very smooth chocolate flavor that finishes with a hint of fruit.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Pours a dark brown/black with a beige head. Nice aroma of dark roast, malt, nuts. Flavor of dark roast, malt, nuts and alcohol. Mouth feel is medium body with medium high carbonation. Overall, very tasty porter!

Bottle courtesy of ilovedarkbeer. Dark brown that lightens towards the top. Has a doughy aroma with hints of fruit. Alcohol is felt on the nose. Roasted and smoky on the taste. Bits of heavy malt. Nice and complex. Fairly heavy sitting also.

Bomber courtesy of hellbilly. Aroma at first was sweet ginger and cinnamon licorice candy. Second pour aroma more of a roasty nose. Sweet candy laquers the palate along with the ginger and some roasty malt in the mix. Second glass from bomber was more roasted malt and thicker body texture. One of those complex brews had so much going on with it. Enjoyable brew thanks Josh.

Appearance: Pours out a dark brown, near black body with a smallish, ivory-hued head.

Smell: Surprisingly simple nose smelling lightly of roasted barley, unsweetened chocolate, licorice, and, well, thats about it.

Taste: Roasted barley with sweetish, somewhat diluted tastes of basic chocolate, caramel, and licorice. Low earthy, roasty bitterness. Darkened grains and hints of dark fruits. Roast and a warming alcohol presence on the otherwise light, clean finish. A "killer" it is not.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-low carbonation.

Drinkability: The tastes within were subtler and far more understated than Id prefer. Also, the body seemed a bit on the lean side. While Im happy to have gotten the chance to try this, it just didnt win me over.
Bomber.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of roasted malt, pepper, fruity. Tastes of roasted malt, chocolate, touches of coffee, burnt licorice, some nice bitterness on the finish.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Pre ZBF thanks to Urbs.Good black and tan looks. Fruity and malty with some slight bread. Faint chocolate and fruit but not enough complexity to really make it sing. A fairly basic Baltic porter but enjoyable all the same.
Attractive deep brown pout with a thin tan head. Nose and flavor were sweet and metallic. Iron like. That was overwhelming any other influence. Full mouthfeel.

Liquid Sunshine VII Tasting  Kirkland, WA
Aroma: Dark malt aroma with a strong alcohol aroma with chocolate.   
Appearance: Black in color, Clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big dark malt beer with lots of alcohol with chocolate flavors the smoke also lingers.     
Palate: Dry Strong Baltic Finish, with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Big beer this was it would catch you fast if your not careful. Loved the dark flavors and lingering chocolate.
Thin coffee aroma, very dark brown, thin tan head.  Gentle smoky quality, full mouthfeel.  Chocolate comes in the finish nd increases in density.

22oz Bottle. Nice, soft wheaty roasted aroma. A bit of charred tang, and some light bourbon. Calm. Pours a dark brown, molasses-caramel-colored, with a fringe edging sienna-orange and rim in dark khaki. Flavor is even more subtle than I expect. Somehow, a very traditional eastern European character develops first with cool lager crispness, then the pils character, before a more subtle and subdued roast and char. The slightly lower viscosity and the slightly higher carbonation makes this drinkable, but dont quite give it the dense punch that I would expect from something like Koff. Still, fresh, flavorful, balanced, relatively dry, and the alcohol is very well integrate. A nice example. Nothing crazy. Thanks Steve!

Thanks to that mook below me for sharing this brew. I was actually less impressed by this than my fellow tickers. While the pour was handsome enough (though nothing particularly memorable or appealing), and the aroma inviting with its promise of malts and sweetness, I found the body to be way too thin for this style. Missing, too, was the lactic quality that I was anticipating and I found the result to be a fairly solid strong porter but not much more.

Thanks StFun. Pours a dark black with a light tan head. The nose is sweet, malty, roasty, some chocolate. Flavor is chocolaty, mildly oxidized, some sweetness, coffee roast, acetaldehyde. Palate is a tad thin and sweet.

Thanks to Ethan for sharing !  Dark brown pour with a beige head and spotty lace.  Light roast and bittersweet chocolate on the nose.  Kinda thin for the style.  Nice bitterness especially upfront. Chocolate, fruits and roast.

22oz bottle courtesy of wkcyr4 poured into a tulip.

Pours a dark, dark chestnut brown with a small tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a small ring and decent lacing.

There a big sweetness right from the outset in the nose with lots of dark malts and semi-sweet chocolate.  There are hints of both dark fruits, raisins maybe, and espresso.

The taste is just as sweet with lots of chocolate and caramel hitting up front with the underlying malt base being slightly toasted.  There is a bit of bitterness in the finish, mostly from the chocolate and a hint of alcohol burn.

The body is on the fuller side of things with a soft carbonation and fairly dry finish.

This is a big Baltic porter whose complexity and heft border on that of an impy stout.  Its got tons of flavor and body and is another great offering from Flossmoor, who continues to impress.

22oz Bomber on Pizza Plants Miss Buffalo Cruise. Metzger!!! Labeled Killer Kapowski. Dark pour. Aromas of dried fruit, anise, chocolate. Taste was full flavored, anise/ licorice, dried fruits, roasty. One very good porter. Bill, get a keg next tome

22. Thanks, Pantanap! Pours an ebony darkish black with muted caramel highlights and a thin tan rim. Mild chocolatey nose. Gorgeous creamy medium body. Big chocolatey mid-palate with little bits of roast and anise there as well. Long roasty, chocolatey finish. Beautiful, unflawed, straightforward baltic. Delicious.
Kopalski bottle, via trade with STFun.  Pours blackish with a tan head.  Nose is sweet, malty and rich.  Taste is sweet, malty, rich and awesome!
Pours translucent dark brown with a thin tan head. Soft and sweet chocolate taste and aroma with little bits of roasty flavor dancing around it.

Bottle. Pours a dark black brown color with medium to large sized canvas head. Tastes like smoked apple wood chips, dark caramel, cocoa nibs, and a little bit of candied apple. Labeled as Killer Kapowski as a tribute to Ms. Saved by the Bell, nice. Supple mouthfeel and decent finish. Enjoyable.

On tap @ Flossmoor.  Pours darkest brown/black with a thin tan head.  Malty aroma with dark fruit and coffee.  Malty chocolate flavor up front, then dark fruit and licorice with a coffee finish.  Good stuff.

Bottle from BrewCzar - Pours a thin dk brown with a medium tan head...aroma is cocoa, dark fruity malt, fresh hop resin...flavour is similar, dry cocoa liquore, old fruit, a bit of charred wood bitterness...finish is coffee with a bitterness that fades, but the flavour sticks around, almost no alcohol presence...nice brew...

Bomber picked up @ Whole Foods Cicero & Peterson. Opaque black color, beautiful creamy expresso head, lace. Chocolaty, a bit milky aroma. Very liquerish palate. Roasted, burnt malty flavors. Milky flavors like in some sweet stouts. A bit sticky finish. Smooth and balanced, although not very complex. Excellent brew!
This beer is a very very nice baltic porter. its thiner than the duck rabbit baltic or the alaskan baltic but the flavor and complexity is top notch. I can see why this medalled at gabf.

Poured pitch black, but bright ruby highlights when swirled. 
Nose of dark chocolate
Tastes of dark fruits, dark chocolate, bitter black malt

22oz bottle.  Pours a very deep brown that turns to black in the glass.  A thick tan head sat a top the midnight brew (I should be a writer)......haha.  Dark fruits and bitter sweet chocolate were dominant with some coffee in the background.  Medium sweetness, dark fruits and chocolate flavors.  Finish was long and of medium sweetness.

Bottle shared by Sparky27...THANKS ERIC!!!  First taste of something from Flossmoor and I wasnt at all disappointed.  Black at its center but a mixture of crimson and chestnut at its outer edges.  The latte-colored head left a number of sticky ringlets on the inside of the glass.  Aroma fills the nose with bitter dark chocolate, fresh roasted coffee, and burnt caramel.  Flavor is rich cocoa, ash, and dark fruit.  A little smokey and very good.
Light hints of black olives in the aroma.  Flavor has a rather nutty side.  Quite full flavored.  Pretty good stuff.

Bomber.  Pours dark reddish brown/black with a one finger tan head.  The nose is dark fruits, roasty malt and cocoa.  The taste is ashy cocoa, burnt malt, milk chocolate and some bittering hops in the finish.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Very good.
Floosmoor pre DLD ... Deep black ... thins lacing ... deep deep roast ... little coffee nose ... roast malts ... again deep toffee ... more bitter than i like ...little chocolate...

im going to say this one came from noblesquirrel though i got the hookup from a bunch of guys!... many thanks to you all.

it pours brown at the edges but nearly black in the middle with a big ol tannish head. 

the nose is a delicious mix of fudgy chocolate, dark raisins, molasses, toasty grain, spent black barley and faint flowers with a smokiness in the back ground. 

there is a defined ashiness and light sourness hanging around the palate...both are a nice balance to a rich mix of creamy chocolate, barley earthiness, cooked dried figs, wood, molasses and just a touch of sweetness. that tartness comes in to clean off the palate so  a chocolate bomb and toasted nuttiness can linger on the aftertaste.

the medium to medium-full body is rich, lux and soft yet terribly easy to drink as the tartness provides a nice counter. 8/4/8.5/4/17/4.15

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 16oz draft at brewpub pre-DLD. pours damn near jet black with a thick, sandy brown head. aroma is amazing with big, dark roast coffee, black cherry, dark chocolate, sweet pistachios, and big dark caramel malts. flavor was absolutely delicious with big tastes of black coffee, chocolate covered raspberries, roasted walnuts, and rolled oats with a touch of hops and big, bitter coffee finish with a touch of brown sugar sweeness. palate is full bodied, smooth and buttery, with solid carbonation. simply the best baltic porter ive had the pleasure of tasting.

This poured an almost black color with a big light brown head. Aroam was strong residually sweetness and roasty but not burnt at all. Flavor was thixck sweet dark mlants, hitns of light coffee and some molasses maybe as well. A very very good Baltic Porter

Tap at Flossmoor, pre-DLD. Rich, juicy porter. Deadish black pour with no head. Flat dark chocolate and sweet stone fruit aroma. Huge plum and boozy, woody chocoate flavor. A demanding beer, not for the faint of heart. The strongest legit Baltic Porter Ive had. Idve liked to take a bottle to go but I kind of forgot.
On-tap pre-DLD 09 (but with a number of bottles to enjoy later!).  I loved this beer.  Very smooth, great raisin-y flavor and some lovely residual sweetness.

22oz bottle, also sampled on draft at release party.  Pours a dark near black with a large frothy tan head that fades into a dense froth 4.5.  Tangy aroma of roasted malts, light fruit, faint chocolate, some grassiness, sweet figs, a bit floral.  Great baltic porter taste, not too sweet, quite rich, some acidity, bitter dull roast, rich flavor but not exceptionally sweet, very smooth, dry and bitter, slight butter quality, hint of grassiness, lots of bakers chocolate, subtle licorice aftertaste 8.5.  Similar acidity, tannic, fruity, bitter qualities as Stones RIS. 
Full mouthful, slightly chalky and less creamy, very smooth, smooth fluffy carbonation 4.5.  Great beer, very drinkable and quite dry.

CPLYFO 09.  Deep dark brown with ruby highlights, and a foamy beige head.  Aroma is nutty chocolate, light roast, hints of coffee, toasty sweet malts, caramel, burnt toast, and hints of diacetyl.  Chocolate flavor - brownie with sea salt- like the ones you get at trader joes, chocolate and vanilla butter cream with the diacetyl, along with some slight soy and sherry oxidation that goes well with the sweet malts and nice smooth chocolate. Unique stuff.

Bottle shared by Hophead22. Can you say chocolatey goodness? Also with some coffee aroma. Dark red almost black in color. Flavor is opposite the aroma,  nice coffee flavor with a touch of chocolate. Very  nice.

Bottle shared by Hophead22.  This was DuffmanSWs mystery pour.  Fuckin Sean.  Pours a clear reddis black with a tan film.  Aroma is chocolate and a load of roasted coffee.  Flavor has the same coffee and chocolate with a touch of smokiness.  Hints of tobacco in there.  Nice medium to full bodied and creamy.  Full of flavor but simple.  I like it.

Bomber.  Pours a dark and rich mahogany color, glowing an ever so slightly lighter shade when backlit.  A dense, creamy, British khaki head fades to a thin film, leaving broken sheets and splotches of lacing behind.  The nose shows rich, raw cacao nibs, with caramel, sweet tobacco, and perhaps some hints of spicy green peppercorn.  Theres a healthy dose of earthy hops, along with some roasted chicory, all of which works really well together.  Flavors are melded beautifully, raw, woodsy, bittersweet cacao and dark caramel fighting for supremacy, with roasted coffee and dark fruits serving as backup.  Some lactose comes through in the form of mocha, while peppery, earthy hops finish things off.  Bitter spices linger on the finish.  The palate displays excellent balance, substantial and sweet up front, transitioning to a somewhat dry finish.  Very creamy on the tongue.  Really nice brew.  This is definitely up there in the upper echelon of the genre.
22oz bottle from drewbeeme. Dark red pour.Aroma of chocolate and a little coffee. Flavor is coffee as well with a little chocolate, pretty good.

text: 22 oz bomber courtesy of Todd.  Pours a dark mahogany cola with a medium sized light brown head.  Aroma of hay, chocolate and light molasses.  Taste of light molasses, chocolate, cocoa powder and roasted malt.
Bottle thanks to inkubus27. Dark black with little head. Tons of chocolate and roasted coffee in this one. Some nuttyness that goes very well with thte roasted flavors. Very good.
Light on body, and not much head. Small aroma similar to taste of coffee and sweetness.

Bottle at the Alvinne pre Zythos event 09. I think that the CapedBrewsader got this right with the word "ketchup" and cheers to Phil for being great throughout the weekend.  Choccy porter.  Bit powdery and dry in the mouth.  Bith thin in fact.  Its ok but that reminder of ketchup runs through it.

Another huge thanks to Honkeybra for this one.  Crushed with Jakebra.  Very roasty and tobaccoy on the nose.  Flavor is dominated by chocolate, big time, but the good bitter kind, not the sweet shitty kind.  Really, really liked this one.  Velvet mouthfeel.  A great dark brew.

Bottle from the Otown throwdown.  Man I am glad I got to try this one!!  Dark dark brown pour.  Lots of chocolate and molasses in this one. Flavor has chocolate, vanilla, coffee and roast.  Good stuff!!

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a spongy tan head.  Nose is molasses and hay with hints of date.  Slick, medium body; kind of oily with a mild carb sting.  Taste is mocha, plum and licorice with bits of tar and tobacco.  Fruity with nice earthy touches.  Very good.
Sample from a bottle at alvinne. Alround rating: Massivly roasty porter, dry and alcoholic, lots of dry bitterness. Totally not my style.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a black/brown tone with a foamy, tan head that left some good, clingy lacing. The aroma was immediately dark roasted malt, dark coffee notes and some dryness on the nose. The flavor continued the roasted malt nature and added some sweetness and caramel. A full bodied brew with a silky mouthfeel, and a nice, medium bitter finish. Now I can leave my beer locker bottle from the KK launch party alone ...for awhile.

Bottle compliments of Pantanap.  Rich and yummy - this is the equivalent of another great beer, the Dark Horse Black Bier.  I loved it and cant wait to try it on tap.  Bigger, badder and richer than your everyday Porter.

Head only lasting seconds; deep brown, cola-coloured beer. Sweet, pumpernickel bread, and alcohol in the nose. Sweet, very alcoholic impression, sweet bread, cake, wafflessyrup, maple, but somehow, not cloying. Almonds appearing in the finish. Very think, chewy MF, full bodied. Certainly not mindblowing, and a bit strange for the intended category. Yet I enjoyed it - thanks to MvW and Urbain!

650 ml bottle via trade from Noblesquirrel. This bottle is a Killer Kapowski--an alias.  Pours an opaque black with a small beige head that recedes to a fine film.The aroma was moderate in strength with chocolate, mocha, and some dark fruits. The flavor has a big coffee presence with mocha, molasses, chocolate and figs. The mouthfeel is smooth a nd creamy. The finish is long and dry with lingering biter chocolate.  Overall: A very, very good Baltic porter. Much enjoyed. Thanks Brian.

Excellent example of a Baltic. Had in growler and in bottle form. Pours an excellent black with a perfectly think head. Nice lacing. Aroma is bitter chocolate and cream, with some roasted grains. Flavor is all of this and more, with a bigger roasted profile, a touch of hops, candied plums, and toffee. Everything is held almost perfectly in balance. On tap, the mouthfeel is very creamy, but in the bottle this is replaced by a bitter milk character. I could drink a lot of this.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. Flavor is chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, caramel, and rioasted malt.  Meduim body.
On tap at Twisted Spoke. Dark Chocolate noise, smooth palate, sweet coffee notes, barely a wiff of that 8%. Their commercial description is spot on.

Bomber. Pours dark brown with nice light tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits and caramel. Flavor is smooth with chocolate with roasted malts, dark fruit ad some caramel notes. Solid brew like all other Flossmoor Station brews.  Thanks Matt and Andrew for this great brew

22oz. bomber, with thanks to HonkeyBra for my first taste of Flossmoor Station brews!  Pours a dark brown with a two finger tan head.  Aroma is earthy spices, chocolate, molasses, and dark roast ground coffee.  Flavor and palate really shine, with a nice blend of dark roast coffee, chocolate, ripe dark fruits, I guess anise, and roasted malts.  Very drinkable and silky smooth.  Crap, this even exceeded my expectations, I only wish I had traded for a couple more bottles.  Thanks again Andy, much appreciated, and my first Flossmoor experience did not disappoint!

on tap at the release.  A delightfilly rich lager...chocolate flavors dominate with notes of anise and coffee.  very smooth.  delightful, yet perhaps not quite worthy of all of the effort to hand-bottle so many cases -- but i did buy a couple of bottles and cant wait to open one.
Draft @ release.  Pours dark brown/black.  Aroma: Malt, Chocolate.  Has a slight sweetness which evolve to a coffee bitterness on the back end.  Great Beer!!!
On tap on the release date.  dark in color, almost black.  looks like a stout.  great flavor.  chocolate and some dark fruits.  very sweet.

22oz bottle. Pours black with a foamy tan head. Heavily carbonated. Nice tan lacing lasts for nearly the entire beer. Aroma is of chocolate, malt, dark fruit, sugar, grain, and tobacco. Smells very sweet and inviting. The taste starts off very mellow with dark fruit, sugar, chocolate, and grain. After the initial sweetness, the tastes of lightly roasted malt, tobacco, and coffee. No presence of the alcohol detected. The mouthfeel is thick and very sticky. Body seems lighter than it should be, but makes this one easier to drink. I very much enjoyed this one.

Had a pint at the release. Pours out pretty dark, almost opaque, nice small fluffy head. Aroma is nice and malty, a little bit of roastiness, and a ton of sweetness. Flavor is about the same, not too bitter, much more emphasis on the roast, and sweetness. Its almost a little bit buttery. This is great stuff.

Draft at the Brewpub on KK day. Pours an opaque black/brown. Nose is sweet and grainy, with some molasses lurking in there, as well as stone fruit. Taste is sweet, some licorice and a touch of roast, chocolate and noticeable alcohol. A pretty tempting and interesting beer with a silky/oily mouthfeel. Pretty damn good.

Pours very dark with a small head. Aroma is very roasty, some cigar, chocolate, burnt sugar, molasses. Flavor is roast, some tobacco, and dark chocolate. Maybe a bit of licorice too. Alcohol is not noticeable, Delicious and fun to drink, though.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 (Draught)  Pours a dark mahogany body with a small beige head.  Aroma of burnt molasses, toasted grain, caramel, roastiness, plum, chocolate, and raisins.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, vinous, oak, and molasses with a dry finish.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 TAP: at Flossmoor - summer 2008. Dark, roasty, malt/licorice, 8% ABV. Excellent beer!

Draft @ Flossmore.  Pours very dark brown to black with a smaller beige head.  The aroma  was mainly bakers chocolate with hints of plums. GABF 2008. Deep amber brown, almond head. Rich chocolate, cigar box, cedar, fig paste. Beautiful!

Pour is a black with a small tan head.  Aroma is a small chocolate followed by a strong burning.  Flavor is roasted with some peat smoke and coffee.  Tasty but not really a style i like.

As much as I love this complex, hearty beer, it probably wasn’t the ideal brew for a hot July 4th weekend.

Black with a beige head that has no lacing and very little retention.  Smell is of coffee, burnt grain, dark fruits and some booze. Id love to drink this guy again next time Im near Flossmoor.

On tap at Flossmoor Station and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a deep, dark brown with a thin head of tan foam that quickly settled into a lasting ring. Draft. Deep brown/garnet with a tight tan head. Aroma is black licorice sweet with some dark roasted malts. Light/medium body. Flavors are dry black licorice and bitter blackened malts with a light pit fruit sweetness to finish. Not too bad

Pours a very dark brown. Smells malty. Sweet with aromas of caramel malts. Hints of milk chocolate. Full bodied. Tiny hints of smoke/peat. Low carbonation. Kinda one sided.

Pour is light brownish with ruby highlights and a thin tan head...smell is toasty and sweet with caramel and toffee...the tast is strongly sweet at first with the same toffee and caramel....the finish was a little sharp and alcoholic...

thick thick dark black color, thick thick tan fluffy head.  mild aroma of fruit and cocoa mixed with air.  flovor starts thick, grainy, with  a roasty tone coming through.  finishes lighter than i expected with slight sweetness in the finish.  best of the night.
On tap at the 2007 GTMW: Black colored with red tints. Aroma is mildly roasty with dark caramel, alcohol, and lactose. Taste mirrors the aroma and comes across as sweet & syrupy.

Flossmoor Stations new Creation is a baltic porter named Killer Kowalski. Pours the darkest of brown, bordering on black, with faint mahogany stained highlights along the edges only when held directly to the light. A 1 finger super creamy brown head formed on the pour that stayed put for a few minutes before falling to a whispy head thats thick around the edges. Leaves spotty lacing.

The smell is powerful and warming. Deeply roasted malts mingle with coffee grounds and under-ripe banana. Dark fruits abound including fig and plum with a solid dose of boozy sweetness. Complex.

Taste is identical to the aroma. There are no rough edges at all. Every flavor meshes perfectly with the next. Finishes with a sweetened boozy hit with mild fumes in the throat. Very enjoyable and warming.

The body is rich and luxurious. Creamy and velvety with a medium body that goes down smooth. This beer actually soothes the tongue with the mouthfeel.

This is an extremely drinkable Baltic Porter. I could sip this all night long. Until the 8.3% caught up to me anyway.

Flossmoor Station always manages to impress me whether its their special releases like this or their old standbys. This is an extremely well made Baltic porter that isnt over-sweetened and sticky like so many others. They built this beer just right. Another great job.

12-oz hand bottle received via trade with Duane.  Pours very dark brown, some light squeezing in at the edge of the glass, spare fizzy light brown head, somewhat lasting, fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (roasted caramel, chocolate, cookie), light hops (grass), average yeast (dough) with notes of raisins, prune and toffee.  Full bodied, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Short duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; creamy, lightly roasted caramel and chocolate malt flavor.

My 300th Illinois rating!
Pours a deep, dark mahogany with a head that holds as a creamy, tan film. Big, fruity nose of pear, cherry & light prune over a base of chocolate with a touch of coffee. Thick & mildly estery in the mouth with a dry finish. Richly flavored with plenty of chocolate before a fruity, mildly alcoholic finish. Gets very "comfortable" as it warms. Im gonna miss this one...

tap at repeal prohibition festival at Schalflys.  pours almost black/dark brown with a sudsy off-white head.  nose is chocolate, dextrose, and lager character.  The lager shows more than any brewpub baltic i have ever had.  some smokey notes as well.  flavors are all over the place-chocolate, lager yeast twang, with lots of bitter notes (chocolate and earthy hops).  body is a little lite but not bad.  long chocolate finish.  pretty respectible baltic from flossmoor.

Growler acquired in trade with Ughsmash (thanks!). Poured a deep reddish brown color with an averaged sized off white head. A strong roastiness intially hit my nose followed by chocolate, raisins, coffee grounds and some nuttiness. Tastes of milk chocolate, vanilla, caramel, roast, and lighter coffee. Body was slightly thin but smooth and creamy. For a baltic porter, this surprised me with as much roastiness as I was getting.

This was sampled out of the growler in the parking lot at 07 Dark Lord Day.  Dark beer with a foamy brown head.  Thick mouthfeel.  Roast grains, chocolate, and some coffee bitterness.  Nice baltic porter.

Thanks to hopdog. Pours a darker brown with ruby red highlights and a smaller light tan creamy/bubbly head that left some light lacing.  Aroma of coffee grinds, roasted malts, dark chocolate and some slight fruitiness.  Flavor of roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate and some caramel.

sampled at the Hampton tasting - Pours very dark brown with a thin tan head.  The aroma and flavor are both really big on the roast malts and some chocolate and coffee notes are rolled into it as well.  Its medium to full bodied and not much of that 8.3% abv is noticeable.

Growler thanks to BBB63 sampled on 3/3/07: Pours a nearly opaque dark mahogany with a nicely-lacing light tan head. Sweet toasty grainy dark caramel malty aroma has a touch of smoke and dark fruity complexity.  Body starts fairly full, viscous and sweet with lots of sticky dark caramel and a touch of earthy dark chocolate, mild smoke and a drier, slightly warming, full-bodied finish.  A pretty good Baltic porter.

On tap at Flossmoor.  Poured a clear, deep brown with a short, creamy cap of deep beige head.  Aroma was of rich, dark chocolate with smoky accents.. fair deal of alcohol-laden fruits and a touch of coffee as well.  Flavor had a bit of an alcohol bite to it, which just served to make it more powerful.. very well-roasted dark chocolate and coffee with coffee and sticky woodsy bitterness.. warm chocolate finish was most excellent.  Heavier-bodied with moderate bitterness and alcohol kick on the palate.. felt OK, very good overall!
Heavy malt aroma with a hint of alcohol.  Black body with a thin head.  Medium to full palate.  Bitter roasted malt flavor with light chocolate in the background.  Nice.
Pours an opaque black with a light brown head.  Aroma is of dark roasted malts, some chocolate.  Flavor is malty with roasted malts, chocolate, and some alcohol burn.

Had on tap @ the brewpub.Dark fruit,chocolate and sweet malt stood out in the aroma.Pours black with a light tan head.Swet malt,roasted malt and some dark fruits made up the flavor.Medium to full mouthfeel with a roasted malt finish.

On tap @ Flossmoor: Pours black with a tan head. Aroma, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, some molasses. Flavor, chocolate, coffee, very smooth and roasty, some dark fruits. And an earthiness. Quite good.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear garnet-brown color. Head was thick and off white with good retention and lacing. Smelled of brown sugar, bourbon, and milk chocolate. Oily and delicately sweet. I tasted vanilla, chocolate, and malty brown sugar.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 8/2007 Sampled several times on tap @ Ale Fest (thanks for the many pours guys).  Dark brown in color with a beige head.  A nice malt aroma of cookies, chocolate, and brown sugar.   Creamy in texture, really smooth with bakers chocolate, vanilla, biscuits, dark fruits, and hop bitterness in the end.  Another fine beer from Flossmoor. 8/4/8/5/16  is equal to  4.1   6/27/08:  On tap at the Station.  Pours brown black with a thin beige head.  Abundant aromas of bakers chocolate, licorice, and molasses.  Smooth palate with a medium light body. Flavors of dark chocolate, milk chocolate, toffee, caramel, and some dark fruits that lead to a bitter drying licorice finish.  Really tasty beer 9/3/8/4/16  is equal to  4.0

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 on tap, pours dark brown with tan head. nose of dark fruits, plums, raisins, and toasted biscuit. flavor of nuts, toasted cookie, crisp dark fruits of plums and raisins. this is very smooth and tasty. good hop presence. no alcohol detected. a real nice offering from flossmoor.

Sampled at Scholaflys Repeal of Prohibition fest with Beerdrenched.  Pours dark bronw with a nice tan head.  The aroma has dark roasted malt with cream and vanilla - very clean and full.  Medium / full body with overly sharp carbonation.  Taste starts with roasted malt with some alcohol sharpness.  The finish has dark caramel and spice.  This was sampled on a ridiculously cold April day ~ this would probably have been better if it was warmed up a bit.  Unfortunately that was similar impossible on this day.

Hand bottle:  Huge cocoa and milk chocolate aromas with some light roasted coffee and nuts.  It pours a dark brown with some red hilights and a small beige head.  The flavor starts very malty with lots of chocolate and caramel.  There is some subtle fruitiness hidden in the background.    The finish has notes of light piney and citrus hoppiness, roasted coffee, nuts, and faint alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2007 On tap at the brewpub.  Dark brown with some garnet highlights and a lasting tan head.  The aroma reminds me of Raisinetts, very chocoalte and raisiny.  There is a huge chocolate and dried dark fruit flavor as well.  Really makes the taste buds state up and take notice.  Medium body.  Really a top notch beer.
(draught at Schlafly Repeal of Prohibition Festival)  deep black with almost no head. Roast malt and coffee aroma. Flavor is roast coffee, dark fruits, dark chocolate.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2008 I tried this again and really liked it, but not quite as much as the last time. Oh man! This beer was incredible. Flossmoor is a great brewpub and this beer is a stand out amoung many other great beers. The body was very black with a kahki colored head. The aroma was licorice and chocolate. There was also a hint of high quality tobacco. The taste was anise with dark chocolate and some good tobacco. There was also a little bit of walnuts to complement the nice smooth finish. This beer is a scary one as it is too easy to drink.

22oz handbottled by Duane!  - Thanks a bunch! - Pours black as night with a healthy tan head that fades back to a ring but leaves scant lace from there.  Aromas of some chocolate, lots of plum, prune and raisin, and some slight liccorice.  Flavor is amazingly complex as well.  Dark bakers chocolate, raisin, prune, roasted malts, slight smoke, caramel, and a little bit of vanilla.  Smooth almost oily palate with slight carbonation.  No sign of the alcohol.. This one is a beaut and is one of the better Baltics Ive tried.. Wow i really like this!!  Thanks Duane for the chance to get to try this one!!!

Oily black pour, reminiscent of inky octopus attacks, with swirling ruby and chestnut hues that are both very dark and subtle. Thin cream colored head with ample retention. This is a very pretty porter. Aroma is milk chocolate, mellow perfumy yeast, fresh white oak barrels, anise, smoke, berries, light caramel, vanilla, plentiful sweet malt and just a touch of alcohol. Flavor is much the same, with moderate to heavy roastiness as sort of a dessert topping, a syrupy coating. More apparent alcohol and a unique woodiness. Chocolate resembles fresh fudge, like on half cooked brownies. At first the carbonation seems abrasive but keeps this lively. Mouthfeel is slick but full and heavy. Finishes chocolatey and mildly warming. Excellent. A crowning achievement for a top notch brewpub.

growler.  pours a dark brown with a light mahogany, rubyish edge and a short-lived tan head.  aroma is sweet malts with some chocolate.  flavor is more sweet malts, dark ripe fruit and some bittersweet chocolate.  mouthfeel is slightly oily with mild carbonation and a slightly acidic finish.  my first beer from Flossmoor and it did not disappoint.

Growler, via Drnk_McDermott.  Pours a burnt caramel brown under a fairly small large bubbled head with minimal retention.  Aroma is licorice, caramel, and chocolate primarily with some roast, light alcohol, and cocoa.  Flavor has lots of caramel and roast up front followed by lots of licorice and alcohol on the finish.  Very clean and lacking in the fruitiness found with most top fermented Baltic Porters.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly oily with light carbonation.  Feels like maybe a little bit of CO2 has been lost which may also account for the less than impressive head formation.  A pretty darn nice beer all the same though.  Seems to really follow in the true tradition of Baltic Porters.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2007 Growler... St. Patricks Day 2007... This beer rocks!...  Dark, clear ruby lager with a small, creamy, beige head. Roasted, earthy nose with notes of chocolate, smoked meat and resin. The flavor is more bitter and charred than sweet with bold chocolate and tobacco. I didnt pick up any fruity notes in the nose or flavor. Full-bodied with a whole-milk mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Chocolaty, grassy finish. This is a dangerously easy-drinking Baltic Porter that isnt overdone... for a change. Thanks to boboski for stopping by with this gem!

My second to last sample, this is the one I was most looking forward to.  Since discovering baltic porters a few months ago it has been nice to seek them out.  Unlike imperial stouts it does not seem that everyone and their mother is trying to outdo each other with new baltic porters.  Then again, I could be wrong so if you happen to know local releases, please feel free to send me a bottle as a bonus in trades.  I know with another hour or two I would have ordered a pint of this one.
Aroma / Appearance - The deep black body is the same color as a country sky without a moon.  Only a trace amount of light was able to escape; for the most part it was pitch black.  Cocoa, coffee, blackberries, lemons, peaches and cherry form a very fun bouquet.  The closest experience is that of a smoke filled bowling alley.
Flavor / Palate - The taste of fresh blackberry pie fills the mouth.  It then morphs into chocolate and roasted expresso.  Smoky Christmas ham unfolds next along with pelmani and coffee.  Bourbon and oats complete the last of the transformation before a dry aftertaste of raspberries washes down the throat.  It is an extremely rich and complex beer that can be savored over time.

Growler.  Poured a clear dark brown chestnut color with an off-white head.  The aroma was roasty and fruity with some smokey notes.  Roasted malt flavor with some dark fruity notes.  Fairly sweet taste with a dry finish.  Light biterness and peat at the finish.  The finish was also mildly acidic.  Full bodied with a light syrupy mouthfeel.  Warming sensation in the chest.
A dark cola color.  Small tan head.  Excellent nose.  Very malty caramel taste.  Quite an alcohol kick.  Slight floral nose.  Nice finish.  Not very strong, but really tasty.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 Rerate, had again last night and it really rock, very estery and complex...dig it more with some age on it. Bumping the aroma and overall score by one point each. GET YA SOME!!! On tap: Pint glass that is nearly opaque with a initial small creamy beige head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of prune and fig esters, toasted and chocolate malting, hint of smoke and earthiness. The taste starts with a molasses like twang and an enter play of ripen fleshy fruits leading towards a smoky and coffee-ish finish. Lasting malty sweetness on the aftertaste. The mouth feel is smooth and somewhat lush, soft carbonation that is moderately warming and relaxing. A darn good brew and beer geek worthy, seek and destroy.

Draft. Damn black in its pint shaker with a thin tan head, a shade lighter than on a stout. Deep dark roast smell. Taste is of dark roast coffee with a touch of Kahlua and plums. Creamy, smooth and sweet. Alcohol is strong, but not heady. clean lager finish. Matt says this is going into a barrel as are the Social Lubricator and upcomming X-IPA. Cant wait!
UPDATED: FEB 25, 2007 Good baltic porter,dark black and smooth and very tasty.ABV is well hidden and has a good kick in end .Taste of malts and roasted caramel.A well done beer by MATT.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2007 What a beauty...black pour with big brown fluffy head.  The nose is big roasted malts and dried fruits.   The first sip is surprisingly light-bodied on the palate, considering the deep, rich color,   heavy aromas, and big ABV.   The flavors though are  impressively over-the-top...rich roasted (read: burnt) caramel and toffee malts, dried fruits like dates and figs, and chocolate.   The ABV is bold and unapologetic.
